This means the system breaks both your query and the stored values into smaller chunks (tokens), usually words or alphanumeric segments, and checks if any query token appears in the stored tokens.\n \n The substring search is done using whole words only, and any special characters are searched for also as an ANDed search. For example, searching for -Name starts a search for the substring \"Name\" and a search for \"-\". Substring search is case-sensitive. For example, a search for “Scott” returns both Scott Wilkinson and Maya Scott.\n+When you search the members or owners of a group, a tokenized contains search is automatically used. For example, a search for “Scott” returns both Scott Wilkinson and Maya Scott.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/groups-members-owners-search/groups-search-preview.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of new substring searches on the group members and owners lists.\":::\n "

ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates the documentation for searching groups, members, and owners in Microsoft Entra ID.

The changes include:

*   A clarification that the "contains" search for groups uses tokenized matching rather than literal substring matching, providing a brief explanation of how tokenization works.
*   An update to the description of searching group members and owners, stating that a tokenized "contains" search is automatically used.
*   Minor changes to metadata, such as the `ms.date` and `ms.reviewer` fields.
